LSEG StreetEvents Event Transcript
E D I T E D  V E R S I O N

Q2 2025 Apple Inc Earnings Call
May 01, 2025 / 9:00PM UTC

================================================================================
Corporate Participants
================================================================================

 * Suhasini Chandramouli
   Apple Inc - Director of Investor Relations
 * Timothy Cook
   Apple Inc - Chief Executive Officer, Director
 * Kevan Parekh
   Apple Inc - Senior Vice President, Chief Financial Officer

================================================================================
Conference Call Participants
================================================================================

 * Operator
   
 * Erik Woodring
   Morgan Stanley - Analyst
 * Ben Reitzes
   Melius Research - Analyst
 * Michael Ng
   Goldman Sachs - Analyst
 * Amit Daryanani
   Evercore ISI - Analyst
 * Wamsi Mohan
   BofA Global Research - Analyst
 * David Vogt
   UBS - Analyst
 * Samik Chatterjee
   JPMorgan - Analyst
 * Krish Sankar
   TD Cowen - Analyst
 * Richard Kramer
   Arete Research - Analyst
 * Aaron Rakers
   Wells Fargo Securities, LLC - Analyst

================================================================================
presentation
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Suhasini Chandramouli, Apple Inc - Director of Investor Relations    [1]
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Good afternoon, and welcome to the Apple Q2 fiscal year 2025 earnings conference call.
My name is Suhasini Chandramouli, Director of Investor Relations.
And we are proud to increase our impact around the world, including here in the United States, where we recently announced plans to spend $500 billion over the next four years.

From starting their morning with their podcast of choice to buying a coffee with Apple Pay to spending an afternoon reading the latest bestseller on Apple Books to using their favorite app from the App Store or an evening workout with Fitness+, Apple's Services are enriching our users' lives all throughout their day.

However, for some color, assuming the current global tariff rates, policies, and applications do not change for the balance of the quarter and no new tariffs are added, we estimate the impact to add $900 million to our costs.

For our part, we will manage the company the way we always have, with thoughtful and deliberate decisions, with a focus on investing for the long term, and with dedication to innovation and the possibilities it creates.
Operating cash flow was also strong at $24 billion.
Organizations are investing more on Apple products and services to drive productivity and employee engagement.
We ended the quarter with $133 billion in cash and marketable securities.
We had $3 billion in debt maturities and increased commercial paper by $4 billion, resulting in $98 billion in total debt.
Therefore, at the end of the quarter, net cash was $35 billion.
During the quarter, we returned $29 billion to shareholders.
This included $3.8 billion in dividends and equivalents and $25 billion through open-market repurchases of 108 million Apple shares.

Given the continued confidence we have in our business now and into the future, today, our Board authorized an additional $100 billion for share repurchases as we maintain our goal of getting to net cash neutral.
We expect gross margin to be between 45.5% and 46.5%, which includes the estimated impact of the $900 million of tariff-related costs that Tim referred to earlier.
We expect OI&E to be around negative $300 million, excluding any potential impact from the mark-to-market of minority investments and our tax rate to be around 16%.

And so if you -- for the June quarter, as I talked about in my opening comments, we estimate the impact, assuming that the current global tariff, rates, policies, and applications don't change for the balance of the quarter, to be $900 million to our costs.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Ben Reitzes, Melius Research - Analyst    [7]
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Tim, if you had told me that on April 2 that your hit from tariffs was only a $0.05-ish a quarter at $900 million, that would have been a pretty good outcome, given the panic that ensued.

Tim, I think when you talked about the $900 million impact to your cost of goods sold, you sort of had a statement that there are certain unique factors that benefit you in the June quarter related to that number.
You quantified a $900 million hit from tariffs.
When you look -- you look at velocity at the stores or trade down within the sort of iPhone portfolio mix, what are you seeing in terms of how the consumer is reacting to the macro at this point?
Tim, thanks for that information on the $500 billion US investment.
How much is CapEx versus R&D?
Any kind of color you can give on that $500 billion investment would be helpful.

invest_target: expansion of facilities in multiple states
Original_Text: We're not giving out the exact split, but as we expand facilities in the different states from Michigan to Texas to California and Arizona and Nevada and Iowa and Oregon and North Carolina and Washington, there will be CapEx involved in that and OpEx involved in it.
We do our manufacturing through a partner, but we'll be putting a fair amount in cost of goods sold to do that and some OpEx as well, and I'm sure some CapEx as well.
Or is it a matter of R&D spending?

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Kevan Parekh, Apple Inc - Senior Vice President, Chief Financial Officer    [46]
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
And Richard, I'll just add that on your question about investment that we don't underinvest in our business.
We make significant investments in R&D.
We're continuing to grow our R&D investment.

And kind of dovetailed with that is that how do you think about your data center footprint when we look at Apple spending, call it, $3 billion a quarter relative to some of these other companies spending multiples of that.
And as I've mentioned in the $500 billion, there's a number of states that we're expanding in.
We invest in the business first, as Kevan talked about, is our most important thing to do.
A replay of today's call will be available for two weeks on Apple Podcasts as a webcast on apple.com/investor and via telephone.

E D I T E D  V E R S I O N

Q1 2025 Apple Inc Earnings Call
January 30, 2025 / 10:00PM UTC

================================================================================

 * Suhasini Chandramouli
   Apple Inc - Investor Relations

   Apple Inc - Chief Executive Officer, Director
 * Kevan Parekh
   Apple Inc - Senior Vice President, Chief Financial Officer

================================================================================

================================================================================

 * Operator
   
 * Erik Woodring
   Morgan Stanley - Analyst
 * Benjamin Reitzes
   Melius Research - Analyst
 * Michael Ng
   Goldman Sachs - Analyst
 * Amit Daryanani
   Evercore ISI - Analyst
 * Wamsi Mohan
   BofA Global Research - Analyst
 * Samik Chatterjee
   JPMorgan - Analyst
 * David Vogt
   UBS Equities - Analyst
 * Sreekrishnan Sankarnarayanan
   TD Cowen - Analyst
 * Richard Kramer
   Arete Research - Analyst
 * Atif Malik
   Citi - Analyst
 * Benjamin Bollin
   Cleveland Research Company - Analyst

================================================================================
presentation
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Suhasini Chandramouli, Apple Inc - Investor Relations    [1]
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Good afternoon, and welcome to the Apple Q1 fiscal year 2025 earnings conference call.
My name is Suhasini Chandramouli, Director of Investor Relations.
And in the past year, we've seen nearly $100 billion in revenue from our services business.
And we were excited to recently begin our international expansion with Apple Intelligence now available in Australia, Canada, New Zealand, South Africa, and the UK.
We're going to keep investing in innovation and in transformative tools that help users in their everyday lives.
In Mac, revenue was $9 billion for the December quarter, 16% higher year over year, driven by significant excitement around the world for our latest Mac lineup.
Products revenue was $98 billion, up 2% year over year, driven by growth from iPad and Mac.
Mac generated $9 billion in revenue, up 16% year over year.

We remain focused on improving the breadth and quality of our Services offerings, from new games in Apple Arcade to exciting new programming on Fitness+ and the continued expansion of features like Tap to Pay now live in 20 markets.
We ended the quarter with $141 billion in cash and marketable securities.
We repaid $1 billion in maturing debt and decreased commercial paper by $8 billion, resulting in $97 billion in total debt.
Therefore, net cash at the end of the quarter was $45 billion.
During the quarter, we returned over $30 billion to shareholders.
We expect OI&E to be around negative $300 million, excluding any potential impact from the mark-to-market of minority investments, and our tax rate to be around 16%.
And from a CapEx point of view, we've always taken a very prudent and deliberate approach to our expenditure, and we continue to leverage a hybrid model, which I think continues to serve us well.
So we have, as you know, a very broad Services portfolio.
And one of the things, as an important reminder, is we've got a very broad services portfolio.
And so one of the big factors that drive the services gross margins and relative performance of those different businesses within the portfolio.
Or is it a question of money, i.e., shifting R&D or marketing spend towards AI?
A replay of today's call will be available for two weeks on Apple Podcasts or as a webcast on apple.com/investor and via telephone.

Refinitiv StreetEvents Event Transcript
E D I T E D   V E R S I O N

Q3 2024 Apple Inc Earnings Call
AUGUST 01, 2024 / 9:00PM GMT

================================================================================
Corporate Participants
================================================================================

 * Luca Maestri
   Apple Inc - Chief Financial Officer, Senior Vice President
 * Suhasini Chandramouli
   Apple Inc - Director of Investor Relations
 * Timothy Cook
   Apple Inc - Chief Executive Officer, Director

================================================================================
Conference Call Participiants
================================================================================

 * Krish Sankar
   TD Cowen and Company, LLC - Analyst
 * Atif Malik
   Citigroup Inc. - Analyst
 * Amit Daryanani
   Evercore ISI Institutional Equities - Analyst
 * Samik Chatterjee
   JPMorgan Chase & Co - Analyst
 * Richard Kramer
   Arete Research Services LLP - Analyst
 * Benjamin Reitzes
   Melius Research LLC - Analyst
 * David Vogt
   UBS - Analyst
 * Erik Woodring
   Morgan Stanley Co. LLC - Analyst
 * Michael Ng
   Goldman Sachs & Company, Inc. - Analyst
 * Wamsi Mohan
   BofA Securities Inc - Analyst

================================================================================
Presentation
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Suhasini Chandramouli,  Apple Inc - Director of Investor Relations    [1]
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

          Good afternoon, and welcome to the Apple Q3 fiscal year 2024 earnings conference call.
My name is Suhasini Chandramouli, Director of Investor Relations.
Apple intelligence built on years of innovation and investment in AI and machine learning.
Mac revenue was $7 billion, up 2% from a year ago.
It's while we're going to keep investing in the meaningful innovation that enriches the lives of all of our customers.
Mac generated $7 billion in revenue, up 2% year over year, driven by the MacBook Air powered by the M3 chip.

We continue to have great momentum in services as the growth of our installed base of active devices sets a strong foundation for the future expansion of our ecosystem, and we see increased customer engagement with our services offerings, both transacting accounts and paid accounts reaching a new all-time high with paid accounts growing double digits year over year.
We have well over $1 billion paid subscriptions across the services on our platform, more than double the number that we had only four years ago.
We ended the quarter with $153 billion in cash and marketable securities.
We repaid $4.3 billion in maturing debt and increased commercial paper by $1 billion, leaving us with total debt of $101 billion.
As a result, net cash was $52 billion at the end of the quarter.
During the quarter, we returned over $32 billion to shareholders, including $3.9 billion in dividends and equivalents and $26 billion through open market repurchases of $139 million Apple shares.
We expect OI&E to be around negative $50 million, excluding any potential impact from the mark-to-market or minority investments and our tax rate to be around 16.5%.

How should investors think about the monetization models around these partnerships where the CapEx investments are clearly being made by these potential partners, but you're obviously there leveraging your distribution to your very attractive installed base.

And so it's important to keep that in mind if you sort of take a step back, however, and look at the business across the trailing 12-months, it's grown -- the wearables, home and accessory business has grown to almost $40 billion, which is double what it was five years ago.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Richard Kramer,  Arete Research Services LLP - Analyst    [66]
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

          Thanks very much, Tim you referenced the investment in innovation and your R&D sales ratio reached what I think was a June quarter record even before launching Apple Intelligence.
Do you see the rollout of these features requiring further increases in R&D or increases in OpEx or CapEx for cloud compute capacity?
We've been investing in AI and ML for years and in addition to investing more and we've also redeployed certain skills onto AI and ML.
On the CapEx part, it's important to remember that we employ a hybrid kind of approach where we do things internally.
And we have certain partners that we do business with externally where the CapEx would appear in their respective businesses.
But yes, I mean, you can expect that there's -- we will continue to invest and increase it year-on-year.
Of course, an improvement in the top-line helps the margin expansion that we've had over the last several years and several quarters obviously has helped.
On the CapEx front as Tim said, we employ a hybrid model.
A replay of today's call will be available for two weeks on up Apple Podcast as a webcast on apple.com/investor and via telephone.

ANY EVENT TRANSCRIPT.

USERS ARE ADVISED TO REVIEW THE APPLICABLE COMPANY'S
CONFERENCE CALL ITSELF AND THE APPLICABLE COMPANY'S SEC FILINGS BEFORE
MAKING ANY INVESTMENT OR OTHER DECISIONS.

You can find a reconciliation of these measures in our fourth-quarter and full-year 2024 earnings release, which is available on our Investor Relations website.
iPad revenue was $7 billion, 8% higher year over year.
